content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Two possible Lewis electron-dot diagrams for <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown above. Explain in terms of formal charges why diagram <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the better diagram.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Two possible Lewis electron-dot diagrams for <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown above. Explain in terms of formal charges why diagram <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the better diagram.

(b) Identify the hybridization of the valence orbitals of the <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom in the <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule represented in diagram <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) A <math alttext="0.1931 mole " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.1931</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of dry ice, <math alttext="C O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, is added to an empty balloon. After the balloon is sealed, the <math alttext="C O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> sublimes and the <math alttext="C O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the balloon eventually reaches a temperature of <math alttext="21.0 degrees Celsius " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>21.0</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and pressure of <math alttext="0.998 atmosphere" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.998</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The physical change is represented by the following equation. <math alttext="C O 2, solid, reacts to produce C O 2, gas. Delta H sub sublimation, equals question mark." overflow="scroll"> <mtext>C</mtext> <msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mo>(</mo> <mi>s</mi> <mo>)</mo> <mo>→</mo> <mtext>C</mtext> <msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo>)</mo> <mspace width="0.5em"> </mspace> <mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi> <msub> <mi>H</mi> <mrow> <mi mathvariant="italic">sublimation</mi> <mo>⁢</mo> </mrow> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mo>?</mo> </math> (i) What is the sign (positive or negative) of the enthalpy change for the process of sublimation? Justify your answer. (ii) List all the numerical values of the quantities, with appropriate units, that are needed to calculate the volume of the balloon. (iii) Calculate the final volume, in liters, of the balloon.

(d) <math alttext="C O 2, gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with water to form <math alttext="H 2 C O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, which quickly ionizes in water to form <math alttext="H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 3 O with a positive one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math>, as shown in the following equation.<math alttext="H 2 C O 3, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, are in equilibrium with H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous, plus H 3 O with a positive one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math>(i) Identify one of the conjugate acid-base pairs in the equation above.(ii) When the concentration of <math alttext="C O 2 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in water increases, more <math alttext="H 2 C O 3 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> forms. Does the increase in the formation of <math alttext="H 2 C O 3 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> cause the value of the reaction quotient, <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for the system to increase, decrease, or remain the same? Justify your answer.

(e) A student investigates the acid-base properties of <math alttext="H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The reaction of <math alttext="H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="H 2 O, liquid " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented below.<math alttext="H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, are in equilibrium with H 2 C O 3, aqueous, plus O H with a negative one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>(i) The student measured the <math alttext="p H " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>p</mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a <math alttext="0.100 molar " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.100</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></math> solution of <math alttext="H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> as 9.68. Calculate the concentration of <math alttext="O H with a negative one charge, aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution.<math alttext="K sub b equals the fraction with numerator the molar concentration of H 2 C O 3, times, the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge, and denominator the molar concentration of H C O 3 with a negative one charge, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>(ii) The <math alttext="K sub b " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the reaction of <math alttext="H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> with <math alttext="H 2 O, liquid " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is given above. Calculate the value of <math alttext="K sub b " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction.(iii) The student then carried out a second experiment at the same temperature to determine <math alttext="K sub b " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. In the experiment, the student measured the <math alttext="p H " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>p</mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></math> of <math alttext="0.300 molar H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.300</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><msup><mrow><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Would the value of <math alttext="K sub b " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> calculated in the second experiment be greater than, less than, or equal to the value of <math alttext="K sub b " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> calculated in part <math alttext="e 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>e</mtext><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mtext>ii</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
